cards.back: The study of carbon-containing compounds and their properties, structures, reactions, and synthesis.

cards.front: Why is carbon special in organic chemistry?
cards.back: Carbon can form four covalent bonds, create stable chains and rings, bond with many different elements, and form single, double, and triple bonds.
A compound containing only carbon and hydrogen atoms.
A hydrocarbon containing only single bonds between carbon atoms (alkanes).
A hydrocarbon containing at least one double or triple bond between carbon atoms (alkenes and alkynes).
A saturated hydrocarbon with the general formula $C_nH_{2n+2}$; all single bonds.
An unsaturated hydrocarbon containing at least one carbon-carbon double bond; general formula $C_nH_{2n}$.
An unsaturated hydrocarbon containing at least one carbon-carbon triple bond; general formula $C_nH_{2n-2}$.
A group of compounds with the same functional group and similar chemical properties, differing by a $CH_2$ unit.
Methane ($CH_4$), Ethane ($C_2H_6$), Propane ($C_3H_8$), Butane ($C_4H_{10}$)
Compounds with the same molecular formula but different structural arrangements of atoms.
A specific group of atoms within a molecule that determines the characteristic chemical reactions of that molecule.

cards.front: What is the **hydroxyl functional group** and what does it form?
cards.back: $-OH$ group; forms alcohols (e.g., ethanol: $CH_3CH_2OH$)
$C=O$ group; found in aldehydes (at the end of a chain) and ketones (in the middle of a chain)

cards.front: What is the **carboxyl functional group** and what does it form?
cards.back: $-COOH$ group; forms carboxylic acids (e.g., acetic acid: $CH_3COOH$)
An organic compound with a carbonyl group ($C=O$) at the end of a carbon chain; general structure $R-CHO$
An organic compound with a carbonyl group ($C=O$) in the middle of a carbon chain; general structure $R-CO-R'$
An organic compound formed from a carboxylic acid and an alcohol; general structure $R-COO-R'$; often have fruity odors
An organic compound derived from ammonia where one or more hydrogen atoms are replaced by alkyl groups; contains $-NH_2$, $-NHR$, or $-NR_2$ groups
An organic compound with a carbonyl group bonded to a nitrogen atom; general structure $R-CONH_2$ or $R-CONHR'$
A hydrocarbon in which one or more hydrogen atoms have been replaced by halogen atoms (F, Cl, Br, I)
The systematic naming system for organic compounds established by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry.

cards.front: What are the steps for naming an **alkane using IUPAC rules**?
cards.back: 1) Find the longest carbon chain (parent name), 2) Number from the end giving substituents the lowest numbers, 3) Name and number substituents, 4) Use prefixes (di-, tri-, tetra-) for multiple identical groups, 5) List substituents alphabetically
$-ane$ (e.g., methane, ethane, propane)
$-ene$ (e.g., ethene, propene); number indicates position of double bond
$-yne$ (e.g., ethyne, propyne); number indicates position of triple bond
$-ol$ (e.g., ethanol, propanol); number indicates position of $-OH$ group
$-al$ (e.g., methanal, ethanal)
$-one$ (e.g., propanone, butanone); number indicates position of carbonyl group

cards.front: What suffix is used for **carboxylic acids**?
cards.back: $-oic$ acid (e.g., ethanoic acid, propanoic acid)
